coredata.dc:title: Learning compositional hierarchies of a sensorimotor system
coredata.prism:publicationName: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)

abstract.ce:para: We address the problem of learning static spatial representation of a robot motor system and the environment to solve a general forward/inverse kinematics problem. The latter proves complex for high degree-of-freedom systems. The proposed architecture relates to a recent research in cognitive science, which provides a solid evidence that perception and action share common neural architectures. We propose to model both a motor system and an environment with compositional hierarchies and develop an algorithm for learning them together with a mapping between the two. We show that such a representation enables efficient learning and inference of robot states. We present our experiments in a simulated environment and with a humanoid robot Nao. © 2013 Springer-Verlag.

item-info.copyright: Copyright 2013 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

citation-title.titletext: Learning compositional hierarchies of a sensorimotor system

affiliation.organization: Faculty of Computer and Information Science
Centre for Computational Neuroscience and Cognitive Robotics
Faculty of Computer and Information Science

abstract.ce:para: We address the problem of learning static spatial representation of a robot motor system and the environment to solve a general forward/inverse kinematics problem. The latter proves complex for high degree-of-freedom systems. The proposed architecture relates to a recent research in cognitive science, which provides a solid evidence that perception and action share common neural architectures. We propose to model both a motor system and an environment with compositional hierarchies and develop an algorithm for learning them together with a mapping between the two. We show that such a representation enables efficient learning and inference of robot states. We present our experiments in a simulated environment and with a humanoid robot Nao. © 2013 Springer-Verlag.
